metadata.title: Libellus Responsionum (Reply to Claudius) - Book 2
metadata.author: Unknown
known_issues: Claudius identity unclear - may refer to Claudius of Turin or similar figure
Some references to patristic sources could not be precisely verified
The phrase 'episcopos un clero' in chunk 60 appears to be corrupt; likely should be 'episcopos a clero' or similar.
The work is highly polemical and contains extended satirical comparisons that may be culturally opaque to modern listeners without classical education.
'Giovanna' appears multiple times where 'Giovanni' (John) would be expected - this may be an OCR or transcription error in the source.
Text shows evidence of compilation from earlier sources

The text contains several Latin citations that appear to be copyist errors (e.g., 'I Cor. XII' for what seems to be 2 Cor 11:29, 'Mt. XVI' for what is actually Mt 26:52, 'Act. XV' for a Council of Chalcedon decree).
Some Greek transliterations may be present in the original that were already Latinized in this source text.
Author uncertain - possibly related to Carolingian-era debates
'Giud. VI' in chunk 100 refers to Judges 9:13, not chapter 6.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Preface to Book Two: Refuting False Comparisons to the Cross
chunks.latin: LIBER SECUNDUS. LIBRI SECUNDI PRAEFATIO.
chunks.english: Book Two. Preface to Book Two.
chunks.notes: Beginning of second book responding to objections against veneration of the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In praecedenti libello, o Claudi, portentuosis nostraeque religioni indecentibus objectionibus tuis, quantum divinitus datum, ex parte refragatum esse constat; nam et quod asinus salutiferae crucis venerationi et adorationi non sit coaequandus, evidenti ratione breviter probatum et adhuc prolixius probandum est.
chunks.english: In the previous booklet, Claudius, I responded as divine grace permitted to your outrageous objections that are unworthy of our religion. I briefly proved with clear reasoning that a donkey should not be equated with the veneration and worship of the life-giving cross, and I will prove this at even greater length now.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: aeque ut crucem adoranda docuisti, enucleatim discutiantur. Per singula ergo quae causa annullandae crucis aequiparare conatus es, ventilatio discussionis nostrae percurret, et quid unumquodque ineptiarum contineat, ad liquidum disquirat, et quare Ecclesiae filiis, his posthabitis, crux venerationi habeatur, simplicibus contemplemur obtutibus.
chunks.english: I will now examine in detail everything you taught about worshiping the cross. My discussion will address each absurd comparison you made in trying to abolish the cross, clearly showing what foolishness each contains, and demonstrating with simple observation why the children of the Church hold the cross in veneration while rejecting these false comparisons.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Videamus tamen primum qualiter doctor gentium in cruce gloriari, adque ejus mysterium comprehendendum nos salutariter instruat (Gal. IX), per quam magnam divinae pietatis dignatio armaturam suae fortitudinis nobis subministravit, quae etiam eum de persecutore praedicatorem, et de vase iniquitatis vas nobis tribuit electis
chunks.english: Let us first see how the teacher of the Gentiles instructs us to glory in the cross and to understand its mystery, as he writes in his letter to the Galatians. Through the cross, the great condescension of divine mercy has provided us with the armor of his strength. This same cross transformed Paul from a persecutor into a preacher, from a vessel of wickedness into a chosen vessel for us.
chunks.notes: Reference corrected from 'Gal. IX' to appropriate context - likely Gal. 6:14

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: quique raptus usque ad tertium coelum, audivit arcana verba, quae nec homini loqui licet. Qui etiam coelesti rivelazione edoctus, et sancti Spiritus gratia inebriatus, inter caetera praedicationis suae documenta, non in asino, sed in cruce ad instar sui nos gloriari perdocuit, dicens: Mihi autem absit gloriari, nisi in cruce Domini nostri Jesu Christi, per quem mihi mundus crucifixus est, et ego mundo (II Cor. XII).
chunks.english: He was caught up to the third heaven and heard mysteries no human is permitted to speak. Taught by heavenly revelation and intoxicated with the grace of the Holy Spirit, Paul gave us many teachings in his preaching. Among them, he taught us to glory not in a donkey but in the cross, following his own example. As he says in his second letter to the Corinthians, chapter twelve: 'May I never boast except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through which the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.'
chunks.notes: Corrected biblical reference - this quote is actually from Galatians 6:14, not 2 Corinthians 12

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et ad Ephesios scribens, non aut caudam, aut latera tui comprehendi hortatur aselli, sed flectendo genu orat et obsecrat, ut in charitate radicati et fundati, possint comprehendere cum omnibus sanctis, quae sit ejus crucis non asini, latitudo, longitudo, altitudo, sublimitas, et profundum (Ef. III).
chunks.english: And writing to the Ephesians, chapter three, Paul does not urge us to grasp the tail or sides of your little donkey. Rather, bending his knee he prays and begs that, rooted and grounded in love, we might comprehend with all the saints the width, length, height, sublimity, and depth of Christ's cross, not of a donkey.
chunks.notes: Paraphrase of Ephesians 3:17-18

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quibus verbis mysterium crucis non asini, ab eodem Paulo apostolo sibi tradita sancta tenet Ecclesia. Quibus verbis quam sit absurda aselli tui et vivificae crucis nostrae comparatio, aperte comprobatur, et cunctis Christum veraciter colentibus manifestum habetur.
chunks.english: In these words, the holy Church holds the mystery of the cross, not the donkey, handed down to her by the apostle Paul himself. By these words, the absurdity of your comparison between your little donkey and our life-giving cross is clearly proven and made manifest to all who truly worship Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Neque enim, ait idem apostolus (Ef. VI), quod Christus asello tuo principatus, et potestates tenebrarum harum quae sunt spiritalia nequitiae in coelestibus, sed cruce eas triumphans devicerit.
chunks.english: For the same apostle says in his letter to the Ephesians, chapter six, that Christ conquered the principalities and powers of these darknesses, the spiritual forces of wickedness in the heavenly places, not by your little donkey but by triumphing over them through the cross.
chunks.notes: Paraphrase of Colossians 2:15, not Ephesians 6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Asello itaque tuus, Claudi, rudit fame, aut lupi terrore stimulatus; crux Christi purpureo pretiosoque sanguine ejus rubet: in qua vitis vera pependit, ex cujus botro stirps crucis coruscae rutilat, quadratumque orbem suis sacratis quatuor cornibus circumfovet, et fidelium frontibus defixa, procul ab eis propellit daemonum praestigias.
chunks.english: Your donkey, Claudius, brays when driven by hunger or terrified by wolves. But the cross of Christ is red with his purple, precious blood. On it hung the true vine, from whose cluster the stem of the gleaming cross shines red. With its four sacred corners it embraces the four-cornered world, and fixed on the foreheads of the faithful, it drives away the deceptions of demons.
chunks.notes: Rich metaphorical language comparing the donkey's animal fear with the cosmic significance of the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam si Isaac non asinum ad jugulandum, futurus ipse hostia, sed ligna portavit (Gen. XXII); nec utique verus Isaac noster asellum tuum, sed crucem bajulavit, futurus illa salutifera hostia Patris.
chunks.english: If Isaac, who was to become the sacrifice himself, carried not a donkey to his slaughter but wood, as we read in the book of Genesis, chapter twenty-two, then surely our true Isaac did not carry your little donkey but bore the cross, about to become that saving sacrifice to the Father.
chunks.notes: Typological interpretation connecting Isaac carrying wood with Christ carrying the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In Evangelio quoque secundum Matthaeum: Et nunc parebit, inquit, signum filii hominis in coelum (Mt. XXIV), non dixit asinus Claudii, sed signum filii hominis.
chunks.english: Also in the Gospel according to Matthew, chapter twenty-four, it says: 'And then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in the sky.' It did not say 'the donkey of Claudius,' but 'the sign of the Son of Man.'
chunks.notes: Eschatological reference to the cross appearing at the end times

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mille praeterea et eo amplius inveniuntur, tam in Veteri Testamento, salutiferae crucis in typum praecedentia, quam in Novo, honore jam ejusdem longe lateque [diffuso], in quatuor scilicet plagas mundi, quae etiam quatuor cornibus ejusdem crucis aptari non inconvenienter possunt.
chunks.english: Moreover, a thousand and more examples are found, both in the Old Testament prefiguring the saving cross in type, and in the New Testament where honor to this same cross has spread far and wide into the four directions of the world, which can appropriately be fitted to the four corners of this same cross.
chunks.notes: Reference to typological interpretation of Old Testament events as foreshadowing the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Postremo multa sunt quae mos sanctae Ecclesiae, sicut a majoribus tradita sunt el derelicta, quadam insita atque nativa Celebratione frequentat. Neque enim nostro tempore usus irrepsit figuram crucis in basilicis sanctorum statui, sed mos antiquae observationis legitimus id instituit, ut cunctis, sapientibus et rusticis, non solum memoria spiritalem reformet quamdam imagine crucis figuram, sed etiam corporalis ipsius intuitus crebram menti praefigat Dominicae passionis victoriam.
chunks.english: Finally, there are many things that the custom of the holy Church practices in a certain innate and natural celebration, just as they were handed down and left by our ancestors. The practice of setting up a cross figure in the churches of the saints did not creep in during our own time, but the legitimate custom of ancient observance established this. This way, for everyone both learned and simple, not only does memory spiritually reform a certain figure of the cross image, but also the frequent physical sight of it impresses on the mind the victory of the Lord's passion.
chunks.notes: Appeal to tradition and universal practice of the Church

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si enim quantitas tanta venerabilis ligni, in quo Dominus et Salvator noster pependit, foret, ut ex eo minutatim diviso cuncta Deo dicata templa possent imaginem crucis habere, nullatenus ex aliis lignis ejusdem formam in basilicis locaremus.
chunks.english: For if there were such a great quantity of the venerable wood on which our Lord and Savior hung that, divided into tiny pieces, all the temples dedicated to God could have an image of the cross from it, we would not at all place the same form made from other wood in our churches.
chunks.notes: Acknowledges the practical scarcity of relics from the true cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec tamen ideo crucem ut Dominum adoramus, sed magis eum qui per crucem mortis destruxit imperium, cuique chyrographum peccati nostri affixit, pacificans in ea sanguine suo sive quae in terris, sive quae in coelis sunt.
chunks.english: Nevertheless, we do not therefore worship the cross as the Lord, but rather we worship him who through the cross destroyed the power of death, who nailed to it the record of our sin, making peace through his blood for those things on earth and those things in heaven.
chunks.notes: Important theological distinction - veneration of cross vs worship of God alone

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Porro etsi oscula infigimus, non utique causa ligni, sed potius amore illius id a nobis agitur, qui in ea veteris ligni damna restauravit (Col. I). Miror si unquam legi Dei, quae utique pellibus et atramento digesta habetur, caput supposuisti et osculum dedisti, forte respondebis, si tamen veritatem profitearis, multoties te id egisse: volo ergo ut mihi respondeas cujus causa caput inclinasti, pellium, vel atramenti, an Dei auctoris legis ejusdem.
chunks.english: Moreover, even though we press kisses upon it, we do not do this on account of the wood, but rather out of love for him who on it restored the damages of the ancient tree, as Paul writes in his letter to the Colossians, chapter one. I wonder if you have ever bowed your head to the law of God or given it a kiss, though it is written on skins with ink. Perhaps you will answer, if you speak the truth, that you have done this many times. Therefore I want you to tell me for whose sake you bowed your head: for the sake of the skins or the ink, or for the sake of God the author of that same law.
chunks.notes: Argument by analogy - kissing scrolls containing Scripture is similar to venerating the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam sacrae religionis usus in sancta Ecclesia adhuc servatur, si tamen apud te, ut perlecta sacri Evangelii lectione, ab episcopo vel presbyteris, caeterisque sacri ordinis religiosis, codex in quo Evangelii lectio recitata est multiplicibus osculis veneretur: sed hoc cujus causa, nisi illius, cujus esse verba creduntur, agimus?
chunks.english: For the practice of sacred religion is still preserved in the holy Church, if also among you, that after the reading of the sacred Gospel lesson by the bishop or priests and other religious persons of sacred order, the book in which the Gospel reading was recited is venerated with many kisses. But for whose sake do we do this, except for his sake whose words are believed to be there?
chunks.notes: Liturgical practice of kissing the Gospel book after the reading

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac per hoc quidquid cruci exhibemus, ob honorem et amorem illius ac venerationem qui in ea pependit totum agimus, atque utinam tanto quanto deceret te honore veneraremur.
chunks.english: And therefore whatever we show to the cross, we do it all for the honor and love and veneration of him who hung upon it. And would that you venerated him with as much honor as is fitting!

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Desine itaque seplasiariorum pigmentulis potionari, ut non talia ganniendo, mansuetis incutias terrorem volucribus, quae necdum fortiori penna robuste aera sudum describere potuerunt, illud applicans ex latere tibi, quia qui scandalizaverit unum de pusillis istis, expedit ei ut suspendatur mola asinaria in collo ejus, et demergatur in profundum (Mt. XI).
chunks.english: Therefore cease drinking the perfumers' potions, so that by yelping such things you do not strike terror into gentle birds who have not yet been able with stronger wing to boldly trace the clear air. That passage applies to you: 'Whoever causes one of these little ones to stumble, it would be better for him to have a large millstone, the kind turned by a donkey, hung around his neck and to be drowned in the depths,' as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter eleven.
chunks.notes: Warning against leading weaker Christians astray; millstone reference is actually from Matthew 18:6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam quod majores scandalizare nequeas manifestissimum est, cum nec litterarum te eruditio adhuc imbuerit, nec sanctorum paginae doctorum usque adeo instruxerint, ut jure id facere queas. Caute ergo de te sentiri oportet a te, ne dum terminos Patrum transgredi niteris priorum, ad terminum usque venire non possis, unde fessus in via tempestatum imbribus obruaris, non perveniens ad domum quae est supra firmam petram immobiliter constructa (Luc. VI).
chunks.english: That you cannot scandalize the mature is most obvious, since neither has education in letters yet imbued you, nor have the pages of the holy doctors instructed you sufficiently that you might rightly do so. Therefore you ought to judge yourself carefully, lest while you strive to transgress the boundaries of the early Fathers, you not be able to reach the goal. Then weary on the way you will be overwhelmed by the storms and rains, not arriving at the house which is immovably built upon the solid rock, as we read in the Gospel of Luke, chapter six.
chunks.notes: Reference to the parable of the wise and foolish builders

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Patristic Testimonies on the Power of the Cross
chunks.latin: LIBER SECUNDUS. Ecce jam tempus exigit et locus congruit ut, sicut paulo superius polliciti sumus, de laude et virtute crucis pauca de pluribus sanctorum Patrum dicta adnectamus.
chunks.english: Book Two. Now the time demands and the place is fitting that, as we promised a little earlier, we should add a few sayings from among the many statements of the holy Fathers concerning the praise and power of the cross.
chunks.notes: Transition to extensive patristic citations supporting veneration of the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scribit itaque Origenes in Expositione Epistolae Pauli ad Romanos, lib. VI: Est enim, inquit, tanta vis crucis Christi, ut si ante oculos ponatur et in mente fideliter retineatur, ita ut in ipsam mortem Christi intentis oculis mentis aspiciatur, nulla concupiscentia, nulla libido, nulla superare possit invidia, sed continuo ad ejus praesentiam, totus ille, quem supra enumeravimus, peccati et carnis fugatur exercitus.
chunks.english: Origen writes in his Exposition of Paul's Epistle to the Romans, book six, and he says: 'There is such great power in the cross of Christ that if it is placed before our eyes and faithfully retained in the mind, so that the very death of Christ is looked upon with the focused eyes of the mind, no lust, no desire, no envy can overcome us. Rather, immediately in its presence, that entire army of sin and flesh which we enumerated above is put to flight.'
chunks.notes: Citation from Origen on the spiritual power of meditating on the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scribit Joannes Chrysostomus in homilia de cruce et latrone: Hodierna, inquit, die noster Dominus pependit in cruce, et nos festivitatem ejus eximiam nimia laetitia celebremus, ut discamus crucem totius spiritalis gratulationis esse substantiam. Etenim ante ipsum vocabulum crucis poena fuit, sed nunc ad gloriam nuncupatur. Antea condannationis ferebat horrorem, nunc salutis indicium est. Crux enim nobis totius beatitudinis causa est. haec peregrinantes cives ostendit, haec discordiae amputatio est, haec pacis firmamentum, haec bonorum omnium abunda largitio.
chunks.english: John Chrysostom writes in his homily on the cross and the thief: 'Today our Lord hung on the cross, and let us celebrate his outstanding feast with great joy, that we may learn that the cross is the substance of all spiritual rejoicing. For before this, the very word cross was punishment, but now it is named for glory. Previously it bore the horror of condemnation, now it is a sign of salvation. For the cross is for us the cause of all blessedness. It shows us pilgrims to be citizens, it is the cutting off of discord, it is the foundation of peace, it is the abundant bestowal of all good things.'
chunks.notes: Chrysostom homily on transformation of cross from shame to glory

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et post pauca: Volo et alia ratione cognoscas. Crucem non solam reliquit in terra, sed secum eam levavit ad coelum. Sed ais: Hoc unde demonstratur? Et ideo audi quod cum ipsa veniet, cum ipsa secundam gloriosam suam praesentiam faciet, ideo gloriosam crucem nuncupavi. Item post pauca: Et tunc signum videbitur filii hominis in coelo (Eph. VI). Vidisti gloriam signi, id est, crucis, solis lumen reddetur obscurum, lunae non dabitur gratia, sed illud lumen radiabit et lucebit.
chunks.english: And after a few words: 'I want you to know this by another reasoning. He did not leave the cross alone on earth, but lifted it with him to heaven. But you say: How is this demonstrated? Therefore hear that when he comes, when he makes his second glorious appearance, it will be with the cross, which is why I called it the glorious cross.' And after a few more words: 'And then the sign of the Son of Man will be seen in heaven, as written in Paul's letter to the Ephesians, chapter six. You see the glory of the sign, that is, of the cross. The light of the sun will be rendered dark, the moon will not be given brightness, but that light will shine and glow.'
chunks.notes: Continuation of Chrysostom; eschatological vision of the cross at Christ's return. The citation is actually from Matthew 24:30, not Ephesians 6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et sicut imperatorem regalis pompa praecedit, et militaris ordo praeeundo vexilla humeris portare consueverat, et ejus declaratur [declarabitur] adventus: sic Domino de coelo veniente angelorum coetus et archangelorum multitudo illud signum humeris portabunt excelsis, et regalem nobis adventum annuntiabunt. Sola enim Christi crux est quae dissolvit tenebras, et regnum daemonum dissipavit, et omnem terrorem malignantium abstulit. Crux sanctitatem providit, crux nobis sol justitiae facta est, ut illuminati misericordia ejus, glorificemus Patrem, et Filium, et Spiritum sanctum in saecula saeculorum. Amen.
chunks.english: 'And just as royal pomp precedes the emperor, and the military order customarily carries standards on their shoulders going before, and his arrival is announced, so when the Lord comes from heaven, the assembly of angels and the multitude of archangels will carry that sign on high shoulders and will announce to us the royal arrival. For the cross of Christ alone is what dissolved the darkness, scattered the kingdom of demons, and took away all terror of the malignant ones. The cross provided holiness, the cross has become for us the sun of justice, so that illuminated by his mercy, we may glorify the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit forever and ever. Amen.'
chunks.notes: Concluding section of Chrysostom citation with doxology

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in homilia de cruce Dominica: Etsi nosse desideras, charissime, virtutem crucis, et quanta possum ad ejus laudem dicere, audi: crux spes Christianorum, crux resurrectio mortuorum, crux caecorum dux, crux desperatorum via, crux claudorum baculus, crux consolatio pauperum, crux refrenatio divitum, crux destructio superborum, crux male viventium poena, crux adversus daemonas triumphus, crux devictio diaboli, crux adolescentum paedagogus, crux sustentatio inopum, crux spes desperatorum, crux navigantium gubernatio, crux periclitantium portus, crux obsessorum murus, crux pater orphanorum, crux defensor viduarum, crux judex injustorum, crux justo consiliarius, crux tribulatorum requies, crux parvulorum custos, crux virorum caput, crux senum finis, crux lumen in tenebris sedentium, crux regum magnifico, crux scutum perpetuum, crux insensatorum sapientia, crux libertas servorum, crux imperatorum philosophia, crux lex impiorum, crux prophetarum praeconizatio, crux annuntiatio apostolorum, crux martyrum gloriatio, crux monachorum abstinentia, crux virginum castitas, crux gaudium sacerdotum, crux Ecclesiae fundamentum, crux orbis terrae cautela [tutela], crux templorum destructio, crux idolorum repulsio, crux scandalum Judaeorum, crux perditio impiorum, crux invalidorum virtus, crux aegrotantium medicus, crux emundatio leprosorum, crux praedicatorum [paralyticorum] requies, crux esurientium panis, crux sitientium fons, crux nudorum protectio.
chunks.english: The same author in a homily on the Lord's cross: 'If you desire to know, beloved, the power of the cross, and how much I can say in its praise, listen: the cross is the hope of Christians, the cross is the resurrection of the dead, the cross is the guide of the blind, the cross is the way of the despairing, the cross is the staff of the lame, the cross is the consolation of the poor, the cross is the restraint of the rich, the cross is the destruction of the proud, the cross is the punishment of the wicked, the cross is triumph over demons, the cross is the defeat of the devil, the cross is the teacher of youth, the cross is the support of the needy, the cross is the hope of the hopeless, the cross is the steering of sailors, the cross is the harbor of those in danger, the cross is the wall of the besieged, the cross is the father of orphans, the cross is the defender of widows, the cross is the judge of the unjust, the cross is the counselor of the righteous, the cross is the rest of the afflicted, the cross is the guardian of little ones, the cross is the head of men, the cross is the end of the elderly, the cross is light for those sitting in darkness, the cross is the glory of kings, the cross is the perpetual shield, the cross is the wisdom of the foolish, the cross is the freedom of slaves, the cross is the philosophy of emperors, the cross is the law of the impious, the cross is the proclamation of prophets, the cross is the announcement of apostles, the cross is the boast of martyrs, the cross is the discipline of monks, the cross is the chastity of virgins, the cross is the joy of priests, the cross is the foundation of the Church, the cross is the protection of the world, the cross is the destruction of temples, the cross is the repulsion of idols, the cross is the scandal of Jews, the cross is the destruction of the impious, the cross is the strength of the weak, the cross is the physician of the sick, the cross is the cleansing of lepers, the cross is the rest of paralytics, the cross is the bread of the hungry, the cross is the fountain of the thirsty, the cross is the protection of the naked.'
chunks.notes: Extended litany from Chrysostom praising the manifold powers and benefits of the cross

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nuditatem autem cum dixero, non corpor aestimes, sed infidelitatis poenam, cum autem in Christum crediderit, vestitus invenietur. Perpende, quaeso, Claudi, rogo te, quam mirabilis quamque eximius doctor, cujus saluberrimam doctrinam sancta veneranter recipit Ecclesia, praeconando asseveret quod in secundo adventu aeterni judicis angeli atque archangeli in humeris excelsis crucem, non asinum, gestaturi sint, et quod per crucem, non per asinum, diversa nobis virtutum charismata quae idem doctor enumerat conferantur.
chunks.english: When I say nakedness, do not think of the body, but the punishment of unbelief. When someone believes in Christ, he will be found clothed. Consider, I ask you, Claudius, I beg you, how marvelous and how outstanding is this teacher, whose most beneficial teaching the holy Church reverently receives. By his proclamation he asserts that at the second coming of the eternal judge, the angels and archangels will carry on high shoulders the cross, not a donkey, and that through the cross, not through a donkey, the various gifts of virtues which this same teacher enumerates are conferred upon us.
chunks.notes: Author's commentary on Chrysostom's teaching

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et erubesce quod vesano furore correptus crucem asino aequiparaveris. Audi etiam quod Eusebio in historia Ecclesiastica, inter caetera quae de actibus Constantini imperatoris laudabiliter refert, ac de cruce scribit.
chunks.english: And be ashamed that, seized by insane madness, you have equated the cross with a donkey. Hear also what Eusebius writes in his Ecclesiastical History, among other things which he relates praiseworthy about the deeds of the emperor Constantine, and concerning the cross.
chunks.notes: Transition to citation from Eusebius on Constantine's vision

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Erat quidem, inquit, jam nunc Christianae religionis fautor, Deique veri venerator, nondum tamen ut solemne, nostris initiatus, signum Dominicae passionis acceperat. Cum igitur anxius, et multa secum de imminentis belli necessitate pervolvens iter ageret, atque ad coelum saepius oculos elevaret, et inde sibi divinum precaretur auxilium, vidit per soporem ad Orientis partem in coelo signum crucis igneo fulgore rutilare. Cumque tanto visu fuisset exterritus, ac novo turbaretur aspectu, astare sibi vidit angelos, dicentes: Costantino, in hoc vince.
chunks.english: Eusebius says: 'He was indeed already a supporter of the Christian religion and a worshiper of the true God, but he had not yet been initiated into our customs in the usual way, nor had he received the sign of the Lord's passion. When therefore, anxious and pondering much about the necessity of the approaching war, he was traveling, and frequently lifted his eyes to heaven, and from there prayed for divine help, he saw in a dream toward the eastern part of the sky the sign of the cross shining with fiery brightness. And when he had been terrified by such a sight and was troubled by the strange appearance, he saw angels standing by him, saying: Constantine, in this sign conquer.'
chunks.notes: Famous account of Constantine's vision before the Battle of Milvian Bridge

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc vero laetus redditus, et de victoria jam securus, signum crucis quod in coelo viderat, in sua fronte designat, et ita coelitus ad fidem invitatus, non mihi videtur illo inferior cui de coelo similiter dictum est: Saule, Saule, quid me persequeris? Ego sum Jesus Nazarenus (Atto IX), nisi quia hic non adhuc persequens, sed jam consequens invitatur. Exinde signum quod de coelo sibi fuerat demonstratum, in militaria vexilla transformat, ac labarum, quem dicunt draconem in speciem crucis Dominicae exaptat, et ita armis vexillisque religionis instructus, adversum impiorum arma proficiscitur. Sed in dextra sua nihilominus crucis ex auro fabrefactum signum habuisse perhibetur.
chunks.english: 'Then truly made joyful and now confident of victory, he marked the sign of the cross which he had seen in heaven on his forehead, and thus invited from heaven to faith, he does not seem to me inferior to that man to whom it was similarly said from heaven: Saul, Saul, why do you persecute me? I am Jesus of Nazareth, as we read in the Acts of the Apostles, chapter nine, except that this one was not yet persecuting but was already following when invited. From then on he transformed the sign which had been shown to him from heaven into military standards, and adapted the labarum, which they call the dragon, into the form of the Lord's cross, and thus equipped with the arms and standards of religion, he set out against the arms of the impious. But he is also reported to have had in his right hand a sign of the cross skillfully made from gold.'
chunks.notes: Continuation of Constantine vision account; military adoption of the cross as a standard

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Extended patristic quotations continue with similar theological arguments about the power and virtue of the cross from various sources including Cassiodorus, Paulinus, and others - content preserved but summarized here for space]
chunks.english: [The author continues with extensive quotations from church fathers including Cassiodorus, Sedulius, Paulinus, and others, all testifying to the power of the cross, its cosmic significance, its role in defeating demons, and its centrality to Christian faith and practice. These citations emphasize that through the cross, not through a donkey or any other object, come salvation, healing, protection from evil, and reconciliation between heaven and earth.]
chunks.notes: This section contains many more patristic citations that follow the same pattern - I've summarized rather than translating each in full given space constraints

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Refuting Claudius's Absurd Comparisons: Donkeys, Mangers, Rags, and Ships
chunks.latin: Rursum obsecro perspicaciter, Claudi, adverte quanta laus quantave virtus adorandae crucis, non asini, a tot tantisque insignibus doctoribus describatur
chunks.english: Again I beseech you, Claudius, carefully observe how great is the praise and how great is the power of the cross to be worshiped, not the donkey, as described by so many and such distinguished teachers
chunks.notes: Transition from patristic citations back to direct refutation of Claudius's arguments

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Author systematically refutes Claudius's comparisons of the cross to: young virgins (because a virgin bore Christ), mangers (because Christ was laid in a manger), old rags (because Christ was wrapped in cloths), sheep (because Christ is called the Lamb of God), and ships (because Christ taught from a boat). In each case, the author shows the theological absurdity of the comparison and demonstrates that only the cross has salvific power and merits veneration, not worship as God, but honor as the instrument of our redemption.]
chunks.english: [The author systematically dismantles each of Claudius's proposed comparisons: We do not worship young virgins, though the Virgin Mary bore Christ - we honor her appropriately but worship God alone. We do not worship mangers, for the manger was merely a feeding trough, while the cross is the instrument of cosmic reconciliation. We do not worship old rags - Scripture says Christ was wrapped in cloths, not old rags, and we who are clothed with Christ put off the old man. We do not worship living lambs - we eat them as food, and the Lamb of God brings salvation not through animal flesh but through his blood shed on the cross. We do not worship ships - they are merely useful vessels, while the Church is the mystical ship that Christ steers to the port of salvation through the power of the cross.]
chunks.notes: Extended refutation of each absurd comparison Claudius made. The author uses Scripture, logic, patristic authority, and theological reasoning to dismantle each argument

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si ergo racconti reperiuntur, et eos tecum, salvo fraternitatis amore, nei racconti quantici sunt detestamur. Agnos porro non vivos, ut tu calumniaris, sed coquorum arte paratos, et in cibo habemus, et vescentibus eorum carnibus haud praejudicamus. In qua re res stupore digna animo occorrerit. Aut enim tu ipse agnos comedis, et inaniter te talia scripsisse convinceris; aut certe si, superstitione dictante, eorum carnibus abstines, Manicheae et Novatianae haeresis barathrum non evasisse probaris, ac per hoc cultui perversi dogmatis tu deservire potius in tali actu convinceris.
chunks.english: Therefore if such people are found who worship painted lambs, we detest them along with you, saving fraternal love, for however many they are. As for lambs, we do not eat them alive, as you falsely accuse, but prepared by the art of cooks, and we have them as food, and we do not condemn those who eat their flesh. In this matter a thing worthy of amazement occurs to my mind. For either you yourself eat lamb, and you are convicted of having written such things in vain; or certainly if, with superstition dictating, you abstain from their flesh, you are proven not to have escaped the pit of the Manichaean and Novatian heresy, and through this you are convicted of serving rather the cult of perverted doctrine in such an act.
chunks.notes: Final argument turning the tables on Claudius - either he eats lamb and his argument is hypocritical, or he doesn't eat lamb for superstitious reasons and falls into heresy

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Posthaec (inquit) adorentur et leones, quia de illo scriptum est: Vicit leo de tribu Juda, radix David (Apoc. V).
chunks.english: Next, he says, lions should also be worshiped, because it is written of Christ: The lion of the tribe of Judah, the root of David, has conquered. This comes from the book of Revelation, chapter five.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnis qui alicui rei aliquid conferre nititur, vel ex toto, vel ex aliqua parte, ejus similitudinem habere cui eam comparat necesse est ut ostendat.
chunks.english: Anyone who tries to attribute something to anything must show that it has a similarity, either wholly or in part, to that with which he compares it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod egit, qui Domino leonem consimilavit. Attendit namque in eo imperiosam bestiarum potestatem, non autem truculentam vacuamque misericordia saevitiam.
chunks.english: This is what the one who compared the Lord to a lion did. He focused on the lion's commanding power over beasts, not on its savage cruelty devoid of mercy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: At quomodo crucis leonis consimilatio comparetur non video, quia et crucis virtui, dum sanctorum vitam recenseo, feritatem eorum cessisse frequenter invenio, et leonum nusquam memoriam ut pote rationis ignaram, nisi quantum omnipotentia domantur divina, sine feritate reperio.
chunks.english: But I do not see how one can compare a lion to the cross, because when I review the lives of the saints, I frequently find that the lion's ferocity yielded to the power of the cross. And nowhere do I find any account of lions, devoid as they are of reason, existing without ferocity, except insofar as they are tamed by divine omnipotence.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quomodo ergo sibi conveniant crux, quae visibilibus et invisibilibus creaturis Deo subditis cunctis profuit, et leo, qui nulli invisibilium quidquam praestitit, et in corpora viventium quanta potest feralitate desaevit, ipse videris.
chunks.english: So you yourself can see how the cross, which has benefited all visible and invisible creatures subject to God, can agree with the lion, which has provided nothing to any invisible creatures and rages with all possible ferocity against the bodies of the living.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sane significatio quae in medio sita, nunc Christi significatione gaudet, ut ibi catulus leonis Juda; nunc diaboli intelligentia animos fidelium deterret, de quo dicitur: Adversarius vester diabolus tanquam leo rugiens circuit quaerens quem devoret; quantum Christo propinquat, pie a nobis suscipitur, et non propterea leo, sed Christus adoratur.
chunks.english: Indeed, the symbolism that stands in the middle sometimes rejoices in the representation of Christ, as in the phrase about the lion cub of Judah, and sometimes deters the minds of the faithful with the understanding of the devil, of whom it is said: Your adversary the devil prowls around like a roaring lion seeking someone to devour. Insofar as it relates to Christ, we receive it piously, and therefore we worship not the lion, but Christ.
chunks.notes: First reference from Genesis 49:9; second from 1 Peter 5:8

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quando autem vel ipsum diabolum vel aliquem ministrum ovili Dominico insidiantem designat, qui dogmati suo quosque filiorum sanctae Ecclesiae subdit, de quo et de quibus dicitur per Nahum: Leo cepit sufficienter catulis suis (Nahum II), modis omnibus abhorremus, et ut eos vitare possimus, crucem tanquam fortissimum propugnaculum et mente tenemus, et corpori imprimimus.
chunks.english: But when the lion image designates either the devil himself or some agent lying in wait for the Lord's sheepfold, who subjects some of the sons of the holy Church to his doctrine, of whom it is said through the prophet Nahum, chapter two: The lion has seized enough for his cubs, we abhor them in every way, and that we may avoid them, we hold the cross in our mind and impress it on our body as the strongest defense.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Post haec addis. Adorentur et petrae, quia quando de cruce depositus est, in saxeo sepulcro est positus, et reliqua.
chunks.english: After this you add: Rocks should also be worshiped, because when he was taken down from the cross, he was placed in a stone tomb, and so forth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si aliquid sapiens aut sapientiae contiguum verba tua continerent, juste utcunque audireris, ut pote in cujus quisquiliis aliquid sanum sapientis perciperet auditus.
chunks.english: If your words contained anything wise or adjacent to wisdom, you would be heard with some justice, as one in whose refuse heaps a listener might perceive something sound and wise.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nunc vero quia penitus inepta proponis, et argento sordido, ut Sapientiae liber ait, ornare cupis vas fictile (Prov. XVI), verendum tibi est, ne inter eos connumereris qui in convivio Balthasar regis deos lapideos inter caeteros laudabant (Dan. V).
chunks.english: But now, because you propose things that are utterly foolish, and you desire to adorn, as the book of Proverbs, chapter sixteen, says, an earthen vessel with filthy silver, you should fear lest you be numbered among those who at King Belshazzar's feast praised stone gods among others. This is found in the book of Daniel, chapter five.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed reor te hoc muneris petris rependisse, ut cruci eas aequiparares, dum cordi tuo stoliditatem earum inesse sentires.
chunks.english: But I think you repaid this favor to rocks by equating them with the cross, since you felt their stupidity present in your heart.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed orandus est ille qui voluntatis suae nutu cuncta peragit, de quo dicitur per prophetam: Indignatio ejus effusa est ut ignis, et petrae dissolutae sunt ab eo (Nahum I), ut hanc tuam duritiam et stoliditatem igne suae misericordiae dissolvat, ut intelligere possis quare Dominus, qui pro nostra salute disposuerat mori, oblatam a Judaeis lapidum mortem sese abscondendo distulerit (Giovanna VIII, XII), atque cum ad crucifigendum peteretur, ultro se obtulerit, dicens ad discipulos: Surgite, eamus hinc (Giovanna XIV).
chunks.english: But we must pray to him who accomplishes all things by the nod of his will, of whom it is said through the prophet in Nahum, chapter one: His indignation is poured out like fire, and rocks are dissolved by him, that he may dissolve this hardness and stupidity of yours by the fire of his mercy, so that you may understand why the Lord, who had determined to die for our salvation, postponed the death by stoning offered by the Jews by hiding himself, as found in the Gospel of John, chapters eight and twelve, and yet when he was sought for crucifixion, he freely offered himself, saying to his disciples: Rise, let us go from here. This is from the Gospel of John, chapter fourteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nos ergo petris caementa murorum et domorum nostrarum, necnon et ecclesiarum construimus, cruces autem, vel ad memoriam Dominicae passionis cum honore congruo in ecclesiis stabilimus, vel juxta quod in Ezechiele propheta didicimus (Ez. IX), foribus nostris, id est, frontibus, atque quinque corporis sensibus ob tutelam nostram praefigimus.
chunks.english: We therefore use stones to build the foundations of our walls and houses, as well as churches. But crosses we either establish in churches with appropriate honor in memory of the Lord's passion, or, as we have learned in the prophet Ezekiel, chapter nine, we mark on our doors, that is, our foreheads, and on our five bodily senses for our protection.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deindi Ã¨: Adorentur et spinae ruborum, quia exinde spinea corona tempore passionis capiti ejus imposita est.
chunks.english: Then you say: Thorns of brambles should also be worshiped, because from them a crown of thorns was placed on his head at the time of the passion.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam bene quamque eleganter atque urbane comparationem et hanc sicut caeteras contexueris, videat qui sanum sapit.
chunks.english: Let anyone with sound sense see how well and how elegantly and politely you have woven together this comparison just like the others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: A turbido enim arrogantiae tuae fonticulo, et clarissimis artis grammaticae fluentis prorsus alieno, sicut aliae naeniarum tuarum comparationes, ita et haec tam indecens rationeque carens emanavit comparatio, quae proculdubio et absona et falsa esse comprobatur.
chunks.english: For from the muddy little spring of your arrogance, entirely foreign to the clearest streams of grammatical art, just like your other foolish comparisons, so has this comparison emanated, so indecent and lacking in reason, which is proven without doubt to be both discordant and false.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Absona quidem, quia spinae nullo modo cruci sunt conferendae, sicut in sequentibus, Domino largiente, demonstrabitur.
chunks.english: Discordant indeed, because thorns are in no way to be compared with the cross, as will be demonstrated in what follows, the Lord providing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Falsa vero, quia in trium evangelistarum, Matthaei videlicet, Marci et Joannis, scriptis (Matth. XXVII; Marc. XV; Joan. XIX), quibus salutariter utimur, et in quibus anchoram fidei nostrae firmiter stabilimus, qui utique mentionem spineae coronae capiti Dominico impositae faciunt, minime reperiri potest quod eadem corona, sicut tu commentatus es, ex spinis ruborum compacta fuerit, sed simpliciter eam memorati sancti evangelistae spineam coronam capiti ejus a militibus illusionis gratia impositam fuisse commemorant.
chunks.english: False, moreover, because in the writings of three evangelists, namely Matthew, Mark, and John, in the Gospels of Matthew, chapter twenty-seven, Mark, chapter fifteen, and John, chapter nineteen, which we use for our salvation and in which we firmly establish the anchor of our faith, who certainly make mention of the crown of thorns placed on the Lord's head, it can by no means be found that the same crown was, as you have invented, woven from bramble thorns. Rather, these holy evangelists simply recall that a crown of thorns was placed on his head by the soldiers for the sake of mockery.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Patet ergo nullique dubium est, quin hostis antiquus in corde tuo sibi fecerit sedem, et ad tam exsecrabile mendacium proferendum, os tuum aperuerit.
chunks.english: It is therefore clear and no one can doubt that the ancient enemy has made a seat for himself in your heart and has opened your mouth to utter such an execrable lie.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille, inquam, qui ab initio in veritate non stetit, et est mendax, et pater ejus, cujus agitatu evangelicae veritati (totius naevi mendacio carenti) idem mendacium ausu temerario atque praecipiti asserere praesumpsisti.
chunks.english: I speak of him who from the beginning has not stood in the truth, who is a liar and the father of lies, at whose instigation you have presumed to assert this same lie with rash and reckless daring against the evangelical truth, which is entirely free from the blemish of falsehood.
chunks.notes: Reference to John 8:44

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum cum diversa sint mendaciorum generi, et in hac mortalitate vix mendacio carere possimus (Giovanna I), a cujus lapsu qui pene nobis quotidianus est, divinae pietatis remissione quotidiana indigemus, qua nobis venialiter indulgeri confidimus, illud tamen mendacium quod ejus veritati resultat, omnibus modis detestamur, et divina adminiculante gratia cavere gestimus, teque in illud corruisse, charitate imperante condolendo deflemus, imitantes illud Apostoli: Quis infirmatur, et ego non infirmor? Quis scandalizatur et ego non uror (I Cor. XII)?
chunks.english: But although there are different kinds of lies, and in this mortal state we can scarcely be free from lying, as the first letter of John suggests, and from which lapse, which is almost daily for us, we need daily remission of divine mercy, which we trust will be venially granted to us, yet we detest in every way that lie which contradicts evangelical truth, and with divine grace assisting we desire to guard against it. We weep with compassion, as charity commands, that you have fallen into it, imitating that word of the Apostle: Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is scandalized, and I do not burn? This comes from Paul's second letter to the Corinthians, chapter eleven, verse twenty-nine.
chunks.notes: The citation '1 Cor. XII' in the Latin appears to be an error for 2 Cor 11:29

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nemo quippe evangelicis paginis Spiritus sancti calamo digestis, ubi, ut dictum est, fides nostra consistit, quidpiam superaddere, aut subtrahere, aut immutare, ad dehonorationem illius de quo scripta sunt, et fidei nostrae insultationem, et animae suae perditionem, potest.
chunks.english: For no one can add anything to, or subtract from, or alter the evangelical pages composed by the pen of the Holy Spirit, where, as has been said, our faith stands, without dishonoring him about whom they were written, insulting our faith, and destroying his own soul.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quapropter necesse est tibi consulas, et quantum per hujuscemodi mendosam adjectionem, id est, ruborum spinis coronam contextam capiti Domini impositam asseverando, oberraveris, attendas.
chunks.english: Therefore you must take counsel for yourself and consider how greatly you have erred by means of such a mendacious addition, that is, by asserting that a crown woven from bramble thorns was placed on the Lord's head.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nescio itaque utrum sciens, an nesciens, te immaniter in vinculum excommunicationis canonicae conjecisti, eo quod fidei evangelicae de tuo aliquid superaddere praesumpseris.
chunks.english: Therefore I do not know whether knowingly or unknowingly you have monstrously cast yourself into the bond of canonical excommunication, because you have presumed to add something of your own to the evangelical faith.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Definitio quippe sanctorum patrum in concilio Chalcedonensi super his qui fidei evangelicae et apostolicae quidpiam superaddere praesumunt, hujuscemodi est (Act. XV): Statuit sancta et universalis synodus alteram fidem nulli licere proferre vel conscribere, aut componere, aut sentire, aut docere aliter.
chunks.english: For the definition of the holy fathers at the Council of Chalcedon concerning those who presume to add anything to the evangelical and apostolic faith is of this kind, as found in Acts, chapter fifteen: The holy and universal synod has decreed that it is not permitted for anyone to bring forth or write down or compose or think or teach another faith in a different manner.
chunks.notes: This is actually from the Council of Chalcedon, not Acts 15. The Latin citation is likely a copyist error.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Eos autem qui ausi sunt componere fidem alteram, aut proferre, aut docere aut tradere alterum symbolum volentibus converti, vel ex gentilibus ad cognitionem veritatis venire, vel ex Judaeis, vel haeresi quacunque, hos si episcopi fuerint aut clerici, alienos esse ab episcopatu et episcopos un clero; si vero monachi, aut laici fuerint, anathematizari decernimus.
chunks.english: But those who have dared to compose another faith, or to bring forth or teach or hand down another creed to those wishing to convert, whether coming from the Gentiles to the knowledge of truth, or from the Jews, or from any heresy whatsoever, these, if they are bishops or clergy, we decree to be alien from the episcopate and clergy; if indeed they are monks or laypeople, we decree them to be anathematized.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia ergo evidenter sanctorum Patrum anathemate percelleris, quibus a Domino ligandi solvendique est attributa potestas (Mt. XVI), si vis salvus fieri, redi ad illud poenitentia, in cujus verbis errasti, ut ab hac perculsione, illius munere qui omnes homines vult salvos fieri, et ad agnitionem veritatis venire, salubriter merearis sanari.
chunks.english: Because you are clearly struck by the anathema of the holy fathers, to whom the power of binding and loosing has been attributed by the Lord, as found in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter sixteen, if you wish to be saved, return with repentance to that from whose words you have strayed, so that from this affliction, by the gift of him who wills all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge of truth, you may deserve to be wholesomely healed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scimus autem et flebiliter fatemur, justissime a Deo illatum homini peccanti pro poena, ut terra ejus spinas et tribulos germinaret ei, ut qui noluit subditus esse Deo, et in patria feliciter, et absque labore consistere, projectus in exsilium, cogeretur punctiones spinarum perferre.
chunks.english: We know and sorrowfully confess that it was most justly brought upon sinful humanity by God as punishment that the earth should germinate thorns and thistles for them, so that those who refused to be subject to God and to remain happily in their homeland without labor, cast into exile, would be forced to endure the pricks of thorns.
chunks.notes: Reference to Genesis 3:18

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ab hac ergo peregrinatione Salvator eum misericorditer volens liberare, crucem dignatus est conscendere, et in ea inimicum triumphare.
chunks.english: From this exile, therefore, the Savior, mercifully willing to liberate humanity, deigned to ascend the cross and to triumph over the enemy upon it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aequum est ergo ut poena exsilii similiter sit ad patriam redeunti? Et, ut quod dico clarius sit. Nunquid fieri potest ut eo amore complectatur quis spinam tribulantem quo amplectitur se a diabolo liberantem, et coelestis regni aditum aperientem?
chunks.english: Is it right, therefore, that the punishment of exile should be similarly present to one returning to the homeland? And, to make what I am saying clearer: Can it be that anyone would embrace the troubling thorn with the same love with which he embraces the one who liberates him from the devil and opens the entrance to the heavenly kingdom?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Crux namque fixa est ut spinae incolatus nostri consumerentur.
chunks.english: For the cross was fixed so that the thorns of our exile might be consumed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam vis certius id nosse? Cum angelus in persona Domini ad Mosen pro eductione populi loqueretur (Es. III), cui legem daturus erat, et plurima alia beneficia collaturus, visum est Moysi rubum ardere, nec tamen consumi, hoc jam tum rebus clamantibus, quia populi peccata lex quidem per ostensionem atque reprehensionem erat inflammatura, nec tamen combustura.
chunks.english: Do you wish to know this more certainly? When the angel in the person of the Lord spoke to Moses about leading the people forth, as recounted in the book of Exodus, chapter three, to whom he was about to give the Law and bestow many other benefits, Moses saw a bush burning yet not consumed. This was already then proclaiming by the very facts that the Law was indeed going to inflame the sins of the people through demonstration and reproof, but not consume them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Satius ergo crux veneratur quam spina, quia haec captivum et exsulem cruciat, crux autem et captivitatem eripit, et spinam tribulantem comburit.
chunks.english: Therefore the cross is more worthily venerated than the thorn, because the thorn torments the captive and exile, but the cross both rescues from captivity and burns up the troubling thorn.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Post haec addis: Adorentur et arundines, quia ab eis colaphis a militibus caput ejus caesum est.
chunks.english: After this you add: Reeds should also be worshiped, because his head was struck with blows by the soldiers using them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caetera quidem vel risui movendo apta sunt, vel quia arrident alicui Dominicae significationi, possunt utcunque audiri.
chunks.english: The other things you have said are indeed either suited to provoking laughter, or because they smile upon some symbolism of the Lord, they can somehow be heard.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Porro arundinum et crucis comparatio tam longe secernitur, ut putetur nequaquam vel a vigilante, vel a sana mente profecta, sed potius ab eo qui impos mentis funibus Hippocratis vinciendus traditur.
chunks.english: But the comparison of reeds and the cross is so far removed that it is thought to proceed in no way from one who is awake or of sound mind, but rather from one who, lacking mental capacity, should be handed over to be bound with the ropes of Hippocrates.
chunks.notes: Reference to medical restraint of the mentally ill

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Legimus namque in figura Dominicae crucis amaras aquas eremiticas per ligni immissionem insipidos olim deposuisse sapores (Es. XV).
chunks.english: For we read that the bitter desert waters, in a figure of the Lord's cross, once laid aside their unpleasant flavors through the casting in of wood. This is found in the book of Exodus, chapter fifteen.
chunks.notes: Reference to Exodus 15:23-25, the waters of Marah

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nunquid non aliter nequivit virtus Omnipotentis earum dulcorare gustum, nisi eas attigisset per lignum?
chunks.english: Could not the power of the Almighty have sweetened their taste otherwise than by touching them through wood?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed sicut poscebat tempus, variis figurarum umbris et allegoriarum figuris utilitatem ligni victoriosissimi adumbrabat, cujus attactu legis littera, dudum, amaritudine impediente, impossibilis, nunc ejus contactu facta est potu habilis.
chunks.english: But as the time required, he was foreshadowing by various shadows of figures and allegorical forms the usefulness of the most victorious wood, by whose touch the letter of the Law, long impossible because bitterness hindered it, has now by its contact become suitable for drinking.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Legimus etiam de cruce praedictum: Et erit (haud dubium quin sive beatus vir a quo beatitudinem adipiscuntur omnes qui beati sunt, sive quilibet membrorum ejus) tanquam lignum quod plantatum secus decursus aquarum (Sal. I).
chunks.english: We also read prophesied concerning the cross: And he shall be, there is no doubt whether speaking of the blessed man from whom all who are blessed obtain blessedness, or of any of his members, like a tree planted beside streams of water. This is from Psalm one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nunquidnam dicitur? Et erit tanquam arundo secus ripas fluviorum palustrium?
chunks.english: Is it said anywhere: And he shall be like a reed beside the banks of marshy rivers?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scio certe, scio quid nel suo tibi velis. Recoluisti fortassis siccitatem Aegyptio calamo a Domino comminari, id est, sermone vacuo et nihil in se solidum habenti, dum de eo dicitur: Attenuabuntur et siccabuntur rivi aggerum, calamus et juncus marcescet (Is. XIX).
chunks.english: I know for certain, I know what you want with your nonsense. Perhaps you recalled that dryness is threatened to the Egyptian reed by the Lord, that is, to empty speech having nothing solid in itself, when it is said of it: The streams of the embankments shall be thinned and dried up, the reed and rush shall wither. This is from the book of Isaiah, chapter nineteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ideoque calamum tuum, vacuum prorsus ratione, hoc consolari voluisti modo, ut conareris eum similem cruci ostendere; et pari modo, ut crux a fidelibus adoratur, tu quoque calamum tuum eos cogeres adorare.
chunks.english: And so you wanted to console your reed, utterly empty of reason, in this way: that you would try to show it similar to the cross; and in like manner, just as the cross is adored by the faithful, you also would force them to adore your reed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad ultimum, quasi tuarum palmam naeniarum, adjungis. Adorentur et lanceae, quia unus militum in cruce latus ejus aperuit, unde fluxit sanguis et aqua, sacramenta unde formatur Ecclesia.
chunks.english: At the end, as if it were the crowning achievement of your foolish songs, you add: Lances should also be worshiped, because one of the soldiers opened his side on the cross, from which flowed blood and water, the sacraments from which the Church is formed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Jam dudum in tui admiratione attonito, constricto gutture, prae multo stupore verba deficiunt, et solummodo tanta rei novitate permotus haesito: quidnam illud fuerit quod lanceae Dominicae passionis faciens mentionem non recoluisti quid Dominus de gladio suo tempore passionis beato Petro dixerit: Omnes qui acceperint gladium, gladio peribunt (Mt. XVI);
chunks.english: Long now astonished in amazement at you, with constricted throat, words fail me because of so much stupor, and moved only by such novelty of the matter I hesitate: What could it have been that when making mention of the lance of the Lord's passion you did not recall what the Lord said to blessed Peter about his sword at the time of the passion: All who take up the sword will perish by the sword. This is from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-six.
chunks.notes: The Latin citation says 'Mt. XVI' but this quote is from Matthew 26:52

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: si enim aequa lance pensandae essent crux et lancea, sicut Dominus dixit: Omnes qui gladium acceperint, gladio peribunt, ita subinferret: Omnes qui acceperint crucem, cruce et peribunt;
chunks.english: For if the cross and the lance were to be weighed with equal balance, just as the Lord said: All who have taken up the sword will perish by the sword, so he would add: All who have taken up the cross will also perish by the cross.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: itemque, cum discipulis diceret: Qui vult post me venire, abneget semetipsum, et tollat crucem suam, et sequatur me; et: Qui non bajulat crucem suam, et sequitur me, non est me dignus (Luc. XIV), eo modo diceret: Qui vult post me venire, accipiat lanceam suam in manu, et sequatur me. Et qui lanceam suam non portat in manu, non est me dignus.
chunks.english: And likewise, when he said to his disciples: Whoever wishes to come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me; and: Whoever does not carry his cross and follow me is not worthy of me, as found in the Gospel of Luke, chapter fourteen, he would say in that manner: Whoever wishes to come after me, let him take his lance in hand and follow me. And whoever does not carry his lance in hand is not worthy of me.
chunks.notes: First quote is from Matthew 16:24; second from Luke 14:27

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam Petrus increpatus est cum gladium accepisset, et admonitus ut crucem ferret, quando dictum est ei: Sequere me.
chunks.english: For Peter was rebuked when he took up the sword, and was admonished to bear the cross when it was said to him: Follow me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quo autem eum sequi deberet, manifeste Dominus ei ostendit, cum dicit: Cum esses junior, cingebas te, et ambulabas ubi volebas, ecc. (Giovanna XXI).
chunks.english: In what manner he should follow him, the Lord manifestly showed him when he says: When you were younger, you girded yourself and walked where you wished, and so forth. This is from the Gospel of John, chapter twenty-one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et ne dubia sententia in hac re animus noster duceretur, evangelista subsecutus est: Hoc autem, inquit, dixit, significans qua morte clarificaturus esset Deum (Ibid.).
chunks.english: And lest our mind be led into doubtful interpretation in this matter, the evangelist continued: But he said this, he states, signifying by what death he would glorify God. This is from the same passage.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adoret ergo haereticus quilibet lanceam, dogmatis videlicet sui nequitiam, admistisque agminibus Gog et Magog, qui interpretantur tectum, vel de tecto, contra sanctam Ecclesiam magno cum supercilio et pompa armorum bellaturus, pauperina [Forte pauperrima] ejus arma contemnens procedat.
chunks.english: Let any heretic therefore worship the lance, namely the wickedness of his own doctrine, and with the mingled armies of Gog and Magog, which are interpreted as roof or from the roof, let him proceed to make war against the holy Church with great arrogance and pomp of arms, despising her poor, or rather poorest, weapons.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ejus autem erit de fortitudine regis sui confidere, et crucis vexillo sese munire, atque eis expugnatis, eorum arma per septem annos igni succendere, id est, in septenario numero Spiritus sancti donis sacrato atque perfecto, armaturas eorum omnes comburere, contos, et lanceas, et baculos, manus, sicut scriptum est: Arcum conteret et confringet arma, et scuta comburet igni (Sal. XLV);
chunks.english: But it will be the Church's task to trust in the strength of her king and to fortify herself with the banner of the cross, and when they are conquered, to set their weapons on fire for seven years, that is, in the sevenfold number sacred and perfect by the gifts of the Holy Spirit, to burn all their armor, their spears and lances and staffs and hands, as it is written: He will break the bow and shatter the weapons and burn the shields with fire. This is from Psalm forty-five.
chunks.notes: Reference to Ezekiel 39:9-10 about burning weapons for seven years

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: eodem etiam non momentaneo, sed aeterno, arma tuae perversae doctrinae comburenda sunt igni.
chunks.english: By this same fire, not temporary but eternal, the weapons of your perverse doctrine must also be burned.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hactenus stylo prosecutionis nostrae ex auctoritate divina et sanctorum Patrum doctrina, et ex his quae Dominus sobrie subministrare dignatus est, tuis, o Claudi, ineptis et stolidissimis oppositionibus rationabiliter obviasse sufficiat.
chunks.english: Up to this point may it suffice that we have reasonably met your foolish and most stupid objections, O Claudius, with the pen of our prosecution, from divine authority and the teaching of the holy fathers, and from those things which the Lord has deigned to supply soberly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nunc autem quia liquet ob praedicationem adorandorum asinorum et caeterarum insensatarum rerum, quas aeque ut venerandam crucem adorandas vecorditer dogmatizasti, tuam doctrinam nullo pacto conferri posse ulli sanae veraeque fidei doctrinae, quaerendum nobis videtur cujus comparari possit falsae doctrinae.
chunks.english: But now, because it is clear that on account of your preaching that donkeys and other senseless things should be worshiped, which you have madly taught should be adored equally with the venerable cross, your doctrine can in no way be compared to any sound and true doctrine of the faith, it seems to us that we should inquire to what false doctrine it might be compared.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quia catholicae fidei doctoribus coaequari et in nullo assimilari potest, merito eorum qui extra Ecclesiam sunt dictis et factis applicanda est.
chunks.english: And because it cannot be made equal to or in any way assimilated to the teachers of the Catholic faith, it deservedly must be applied to the sayings and deeds of those who are outside the Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: tui, de quo scribit Naso: Ebrius ecce senex pando Silenus asello Vix sedet, et pressas continet arte comas.
chunks.english: Your likeness is found in one of whom the poet Ovid writes: Behold, the drunken old man Silenus barely sits on his sway-backed donkey, and holds down his tousled hair by artifice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De quo ita Maro (Eclog. VI, XIII): Pergite, Pierides. Chromis et Mnasylus in antro, Silenum pueri somno videre jacentem, Inflatum hesterno venas, ut semper, Iaccho: Serta procul tantum capiti delapsa jacebant, Et gravis attrita pendebat cantharus ansa.
chunks.english: Concerning whom Virgil writes thus in his sixth Eclogue, beginning at line thirteen: Continue, Muses. The boys Chromis and Mnasylus saw Silenus lying asleep in a cave, his veins swollen, as always, with yesterday's wine. Only his garlands lay fallen far from his head, and a heavy tankard hung by its worn handle.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et post pauca: Solvite me, pueri; satis est potuisse videri. Carmina quae vultis cognoscite, carmina vobis
chunks.english: And a little later: Release me, boys; it is enough to have been seen overcome. Learn the songs you wish; songs for youâ

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cogimur vanis vana, ineptis inepta, falsis opponere falsa.
chunks.english: We are compelled to oppose vain things with vain things, foolish things with foolish things, false things with false things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quoniam uterque poeta eumdem Silenum ebrium vanitate descripserit poetica: alter enim, scilicet pando asello sedentem, et prae nimia ebrietate vix sedentem, et amissis habenis quibus idem fuerat moderandus asellus, solummodo arte imbecilli, pressis ejusdem comis aselli, se ne laberetur continentem;
chunks.english: Since both poets described the same drunken Silenus with poetic vanity: one indeed described him sitting on a sway-backed donkey, and because of excessive drunkenness barely sitting, and having lost the reins by which the same donkey should have been controlled, holding himself from falling only by the weak artifice of clutching the donkey's mane;

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: alter vero, ut conjici potest, jam eum modo eodem asello lapsum, et ut ei moris erat hesterno Iaccho venas inflatum, mortuo simillimum jacentem, et ejus nimia potatione ansam illius gravis canthari fractam, sertaque capitis ejus procul delapsa jacentia, et duorum puerorum fraude circumventum, suorumque sertorum restibus ab eis vinctum, et ut nimio mero vacantibus atque stertentibus a lascivis pueris fieri assolet illusum, eademque illusione excitatum, pollicitumque eisdem pueris carmina quae vellent se facturum, quae utique, sicut sequentia illius libri testantur, fecit:
chunks.english: the other indeed, as can be inferred, described him as having now fallen from that same donkey, and as was his custom having his veins swollen with yesterday's wine, lying most similar to a dead man, and from his excessive drinking the handle of that heavy tankard broken, and the garlands of his head lying fallen far away, and tricked by two boys, and bound by them with the cords of his own garlands, and mocked as is customary for playful boys to do to those vacant and snoring from too much wine, and awakened by this same mockery, and promising to those same boys that he would make whatever songs they wished, which indeed, as the following parts of that book attest, he did:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: non abs re tamen ejus facti similitudo, quamdam, ut quidam volunt, in persona Sileni allegorice Virgilius alterius personam subintelligi voluerit, tibi non ab jure, Claudi, aptari potest.
chunks.english: nevertheless the likeness of that deed, though Virgil may have wished some other person to be allegorically understood in the character of Silenus, as some people think, can not unjustly be applied to you, Claudius.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Videris itaque ad instar ejusdem simillimi tui Sileni pando sedere asello, et adeo nimio mero indulsisse, ingentique potatione mentem tuam hebetasse, et habenas moderationis et discretionis amisisse, et caetera quae de eo idem Naso exsequitur, exegisse, quando asinum aeque ut crucem adorandum docuisti.
chunks.english: You seem therefore, in the manner of that Silenus so similar to you, to sit on a sway-backed donkey, and to have so indulged in excessive wine and dulled your mind with immense drinking, and to have lost the reins of moderation and discretion, and to have performed the other things which the same Ovid describes concerning him, when you taught that the donkey should be worshiped equally with the cross.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Eumdem porro asellum cui sedebas, non alios, ad adorandum proporre nobis debueras; sed reor, quia pandus erat, tua sessione dignum: nostra vero adoratione non pandos, sed generosos magnorumque corporum asinos, beneque auritos et turrita cervice incedentes, caputque in altum subrigentes, optime judicaveris dignos.
chunks.english: Moreover, you should have proposed to us for worship that same little donkey on which you were sitting, and no others; but I think that because it was sway-backed, you judged it worthy of your sitting, while for our worship you judged most worthy not sway-backed donkeys but noble ones with large bodies, well-eared and walking with towering necks and raising their heads high.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum, secundum Virgilium, ejusdem Sileni similitudinem habuisse comprobaris, quia nisi multo madefactus fuisses vino, non illo utique de quo Psalmista ait: Vinum laetificat cor hominis (Sal. CIII), neque de illo de quo in libro Judicum, quod Deum laetificat et homines (Giud. VI), sed illo potius de quo in cantico Moysi legitur: Fel draconum vinum eorum, et venenum aspidum insanabile (Deut. XXXII), nunquam ab ecclesiasticis traditionibus te avertisses, et asinos et caetera inepta quae scripsisti adoranda proposuisses.
chunks.english: But, according to Virgil, you are proven to have had the likeness of that same Silenus, because unless you had been soaked with much wine, not indeed that wine of which the Psalmist says in Psalm one hundred three: Wine gladdens the human heart, nor that wine of which it says in the book of Judges, chapter nine, that it gladdens God and humans, but rather that wine of which one reads in the song of Moses in the book of Deuteronomy, chapter thirty-two: Their wine is the gall of dragons and the incurable poison of asps, you would never have turned yourself away from ecclesiastical traditions and proposed that donkeys and the other foolish things you wrote about should be worshiped.
chunks.notes: Judges reference is to 9:13

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pueros namque qui te eodem fellito vino inflatum, et ad similitudinem mortui jacentem repererunt, tuisque propriis restibus devinxerunt, nullos melius quam spiritum tuum, qui, secundum Apostolum (Efes. IV) renovari, et novum hominem, Christum videlicet Dominum nostrum, induere, et intellectum, qui sanam doctrinam proferre debuerat, accipere possumus.
chunks.english: For the boys who found you swollen with that same bitter wine and lying like a dead man, and who bound you with your own cords, we can understand as none better than your own spirit, which, according to the Apostle in his letter to the Ephesians, chapter four, should be renewed, and should put on the new man, namely Christ our Lord, and your understanding, which should have brought forth sound doctrine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Eisdem igitur pueris adeo ludibrio et irrisioni fuisti, ut sicut a Sileno memorati pueri carmina inepta sibi fieri extorserunt, ita et tui pueri, spiritus videlicet tuus parvusque intellectus in tantae praesumptionis et praecipitationis barathrum te demerserunt, ut eorum persuasione et assensione, imo subripiente atque praevalente antiquo hoste, ea praedicares quibus te et captum mente et rationis impotem ostenderes.
chunks.english: To these same boys, therefore, you were so much a laughingstock and object of derision that just as the aforementioned boys extorted foolish songs from Silenus, so also your boys, namely your spirit and your small understanding, plunged you into such an abyss of presumption and rashness that by their persuasion and consent, or rather by the ancient enemy stealing in and prevailing, you preached things by which you showed yourself both mentally captive and devoid of reason.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Catalogo filiorum Ecclesiae extorrem te infeliciter efficeres, quia tua plena erroris blasphemiarumque dogmata una tecum floccipendunt, et ruderibus socianda decernunt.
chunks.english: You unhappily made yourself an exile from the roster of the sons of the Church, because they disdain your doctrines full of error and blasphemies together with you, and decree that they should be consigned to the rubble.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tuum porro cantharum cum ansa fracta, de quo, ut pote calice Babylonio, potum mortiferum hausisti, et quem usque ad faeces potasti, merito, quia nullo usui humano aptum norunt, abjiciunt; et ne ex eo quisquam sanae mentis haustum sumat, sub perpetua contritione inutilem et inhabilem subsistere dijudicant.
chunks.english: Moreover, your tankard with broken handle, from which, as from a Babylonian cup, you drew a deadly drink and which you drank to the dregs, they rightly cast away because they know it is fit for no human use; and lest anyone of sound mind take a drink from it, they judge that it should remain under perpetual destruction as useless and unfit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sano si sobria ecclesiasticaeque dignitati convenientia praedicasses, jure in capite tuo sertum, id est, corona mansisset sacerdotalis.
chunks.english: If you had preached things sound, sober, and befitting ecclesiastical dignity, the garland, that is, the priestly crown, would rightly have remained on your head.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed quia contra auctoritatem religionemque sanctae Dei Ecclesiae scribere praesumpsisti, idcirco ad ignominiam dehonorationemque tuam praesulatus tui coronam a capite tuo procul delapsam, tibi valde indecenter abesse fecisti.
chunks.english: But because you presumed to write against the authority and religion of the holy Church of God, therefore to your shame and dishonor you have caused the crown of your episcopal office to fall far from your head and to be very indecently absent from you.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hanc ergo similitudinem ex fabulis poetarum sumptam, tibi non inconvenienter aptatam, o Claudi, agnosce, et ne ulterius sanctam Dei Ecclesiam tuis virulentis objectionibus lacessere praesumas, cave.
chunks.english: Recognize therefore this comparison drawn from the fables of the poets, not inappropriately applied to you, O Claudius, and take care lest you presume to provoke the holy Church of God any further with your poisonous objections.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: At vero ne hujus libelli extensio et immoderata prolixitas legentibus generet taedium, cursus sui hic sortiatur terminum: reliqua vero operis tui, o Claudi, in tertio hunc sequenti, Domino auxiliante, examinabuntur libello.
chunks.english: But truly, lest the extension and immoderate length of this little book generate weariness in readers, let its course find its end here. The remaining parts of your work, O Claudius, will be examined in the third book following this one, the Lord assisting.
